awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ICARUS - Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative proposal to build an online, open-access, searchable, central repository for atmospheric chamber data in the United States called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States).  Fundamental data obtained from chamber studies are routinely used as empirical inputs and constraints in atmospheric models. There are nine major U.S. research institutions participating in this project, including the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).  This sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data will synergistically facilitate atmospheric chemistry research in the U.S.

The specific objectives of the project are to (1) provide a searchable public index of the chamber experiments from each participating research group; (2) archive past chamber data from each participating group under their indexed chamber experiment; (3) standardize chamber data reporting formats; (4) provide a uniform template for chamber metadata; and (5) streamline future data submissions.  The data products included in ICARUS are: (A) gas phase data that describes the time-resolved profiles of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as gaseous hydrocarbons, oxidized VOCs, oxidants (OH, O3, NO3), NOx, SO2, and other data; (B) particle phase data that describes yields of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) as well as optical properties, composition (detailed molecular and bulk elemental ratios), and chemical functional groups; (C) supporting information such as relative humidity, temperature, and light flux; (D) the experimental notes required to understand the data (such as reaction timing, mixing procedures, seed particle addition, and so on); and (E) vapor and particulate wall deposition rates that are needed to correct chamber data.  At the end of the 3-year project, the database will be transitioned to the Data Stewardship Engineering Team at NCAR.

por.por_cntn:
The work under this grant supported the genesis and development of the ICARUS project, which is a sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data in the U.S. (ICARUS: Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States). This grant supported a pilot cohort of 13 academic/government research groups to create and test the database infrastructure, perform the initial upload of hundreds of datasets with accompanying supplemental data ("metadata") for maximum usability for end-users, then start to reach out to accommodate any research group that wishes to store, share, and use atmospheric chemistry chamber data in an openly-accessible way. The project development has occurred in parallel with the development of the Data Asset Services Hub (DASH) at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). A modeler peer review feedback was conducted where constructive feedback was provided and updates made accordingly in response, which made clear that most active modelers find ICARUS highly useful and that ICARUS is likely to have a significant impact on the development or improvement of chemical mechanisms and aerosol modules for atmospheric models. Importantly, the database is also expected to be utilized by experimentalists as a resource for design of future chamber studies, and support future analyses that may benefit from incorporation and synthesis of existing experimental datasets.

Our two groups at the University of Colorado have contributed to designing and building the ICARUS database and developing tools, software, methods, and advanced chamber study science, in support of the ICARUS project goal in several different ways. These include:

  • We participated in meetings and online exchanges of the ICARUS consortium, including providing feedback on the design of the ICARUS website (including user interfacing, data relationships and structure, parameter categories, and searchable information) and on the format of data and metadata.

  • We have uploaded chamber descriptions, experimental details, instrument metadata, experimental data, references, and comparison protocols to the ICARUS database. To date, this includes approximately 90 chamber experiments. These data are now publicly available or will be in the near future. They are documented for use by modelers and experimenters. 

  • We have produced protocols for standard vapor wall-loss experiments, physical tools, and a simulation model that can be used to characterize vapor loss in other chambers. Vapor wall loss in Teflon chambers is well known to affect aerosol yields and other chemical products formed in chamber studies and must be considered for quantitative studies.

  • We have developed a new vaporizer for in situ addition of semivolatile organic compounds and organic seed particles to chambers, and protocols for measuring vapor wall loss. It provides experimenters with means to routinely characterize and account for vapor wall loss in chamber studies. It also doubles as a fast, quantitative, and repeatable way to add organic seed particles of a wide range of compositions and volatilities, according to experimental goals.

  • We have developed systematic protocols for quantifying SOA reaction products which will guide and set a standard for future chamber study experiments and analysis in measuring gas and aerosol products for use in developing quantitative mechanisms for the atmospheric oxidation of VOCs and SOA formation.

  • We have developed a (publically-available, open source) software tool for predicting partitioning delays in sampling tubing and instrument inlets during experiments. Building on that concept and software, we are developing an algorithm for deconvolution of partitioning delays from time-resolved measurements of semivolatile compounds. Understanding and accounting for delays and losses from gas-surface interactions when investigating organic compound oxidation and secondary organic aerosol formation in environmental chambers (and the ambient atmospheric measurements as well), is critical for quantification and investigating dynamic processes.

  • We developed an easy-to-use peroxy radical (RO2) fate estimator software to be used in interpreting chamber studies and comparison to ambient conditions and other laboratory experiments. The reaction fate of RO2 has important impacts on the chemistry producing secondary organic aerosols and other secondary products formed in the atmosphere (e.g., ozone).

  • We have developed new capabilities of kinetic simulation software (KinSim, publically-available, open source) to help facilitate various aspects of chamber characterizations and interpretation of chamber experiments, especially related to gas-particle-wall partitioning interactions.

  • We have evaluated vapor wall-loss effects on SOA yields in batch vs continuous flow chamber experiments and shown its importance for both chamber modes. This work will help future experimenters design and interpret chamber experiments to achieve more quantitative results.

Overall, this has been a highly successful project as measured by the products generated and overall contribution to developing tools, a database, and a better understanding of atmospheric chemistry chamber studies and data. For the CU groups it provided many opportunities for engagement, training and career development of students (5), post-docs (3) and a research assistant, exposing them to development and contribution to a digital scientific database; model, software, instrumentation, and method development; chamber characterizations; and scientific presentation and publication.
